appendix.title: QSO and QSO Field Validation
appendix.para: When an ADIF file is imported into HamQSLer, the following four validation checks are performed:

listitem.para: Each USERDEF field in the header is validated and checked to ensure that it has not already been included. If this field already exists, the new field is simply ignored. This condition is most likely to occur when you import an ADIF file and then add QSOs from a second ADIF file. This will subsequently occur each time you start HamQSLer if you set the "Reload ADIF Files on Startup" property in User Preferences. See Reloading ADIF Files on Program Startup in the Working With QSOs chapter for more information.
Each field is validated. See QSO Field Validation, below.
The QSO is validated to ensure that it contains at least the minimum set of fields required for a valid QSO. See QSO Validation, below.

Over time, as it is updated, the ADIF standard has deleted various field values, and fields and field values have been deprecated and possibly replaced by other fields and field values, or values in other fields. See QSO Field and Multi-Field Validation and Modification, below, for the changes that HamQSLer makes to support the latest version of the ADIF standard.

appendix.para: Every USERDEF field, QSO field, QSO, and QSO field modification that is performed is logged. Once all QSOs from an ADIF file have been imported, a message box is displayed to inform the user that changes have been made and to view the log file for a description of all of the changes. If no changes or modifications have been made, the message box is not displayed.

section.title: Checking Field Names
section.para: As each field in a QSO record is input, it is checked to ensure that the field is defined in the ADIF version that HamQSLer follows. There are a number of specifically defined fields, plus application specific fields, and user defined fields. Application specific fields must have field names that follow the naming convention for application specific fields defined in the ADIF standard. User defined fields must also follow the formats specified in the ADIF standard.
If the QSO field name is invalid, that field is not added to the QSO record.

section.title: Checking Individual Field Values
section.para: Immediately after a field is created, its value is validated. Each field has a specified field type, such as text, number, and enumeration. If the value specified for the field does not match the description specified for the field type, the field is not added to the QSO record.
The field types are specified in the ADIF standard, and are shown in the table below for convenience.

row.entry: Comma-delimited list of members of the Award enumeration. This data type is deprecated and replaced with the SponsoredAwardList.

listitem.para: If True, the single ASCII character 'Y'.
If False, the single ASCII character 'N'.

entry.para: Comma-delimited list where each list item is either:

listitem.para: A member of the Credit enumeration.
A member of the Credit enumeration followed by a colon and an ampersand-delimited list of members of the QSLMedium enumeration.
For example: IOTA,WAS:LOTW&CARD,DXCC:CARD

entry.para: 8 Digits representing a UTC date in YYYYMMDD format, where:

listitem.para: YYYY is a 4-Digit year specifier, where 1930 <= YYYY
MM is a 2-Digit month specifier, where 1 <= MM <= 12 [use leading zeroes]
DD is a 2-Digit day specifier, where 1 <= DD <= DaysInMonth(MM) [use leading zeroes]

row.entry: An explicit list of legal values represented in ASCII and defined in AdifEnumerations.xml for standard ADIF fields, or set forth in set notation, e.g. {A, B, C, D} for user defined fields.

entry.para: a sequence of characters representing a latitude or longitude in XDDD MM.MMM format, where:

listitem.para: X is a directional Character from the set {E, W, N, S}
DDD is a 3-Digit degrees specifier, where 0 <= DDD <= 180 [use leading zeroes]
MM.MMM is a 6-Digit minutes specifier, where 0 <= MM.MMM <= 59.999 [use leading zeroes]

row.entry: a sequence of Characters and line-breaks, where a line break is an ASCII CR (code 13) followed immediately by an ASCII LF (code 10)
An ASCII character whose code lies in the range of 48 through 57, inclusive
a sequence of one or more Digits representing a decimal number, optionally preceded by a minus sign (ASCII code 45) and optionally including a single decimal point (ASCII code 46)
Comma-delimited list of members of the SponsoredAward enumeration
An ASCII character whose code lies in the range of 32 through 126, inclusive

entry.para: 6 Digits representing a UTC time in HHMMSS format or 4 Digits representing a time in HHMM format, where:

listitem.para: HH is a 2-Digit hour specifier, where 0 <= HH <= 23 [use leading zeroes]
MM is a 2-Digit minute specifier, where 0 <= MM <= 59 [use leading zeroes]
SS is a 2-Digit second specifier, where 0 <= SS <= 59 [use leading zeroes]

row.entry: A comma-delimited list of GridSquare items

entry.para: A colon-delimited list of two or more members of the SecondaryAdministrativeSubdivision enumeration.
A sequence of Characters representing an International SOTA Reference. The sequence comprises:

listitem.para: An ITU prefix;
If applicable, a SOTA subdivision;
A / Character;
A SOTA Reference Number

section.para: There are also limitations placed on the field value. The table below lists each QSO field and validation that is performed in addition to checking the value against data type definitions.

row.entry: Must be a value in the Ant_Path enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be a value in the Arrl_Section enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
The first part of the value must be a value in the Sponsored_Award enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
The first part of the value must be a value in the Sponsored_Award enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be a value in the Band enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be a value in the Band enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.

entry.para: Must be a valid callsign. To be valid, the callsign must be of the format:

listitem.para: One or two letters, followed by one or more digits, followed by one or more letters.
One digit followed by one letter, followed by one or more digits, followed by one or more letters.
One of the special callsigns defined in HamQSLer. At the moment, these special callsigns are defined in the program, but in future will be maintained in a data file.

row.entry: Must be a value in the Qso_Upload_Status enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
While this field is of type enumeration, no validation is performed.
Must be a value in the Continent enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must match one of the country names defined in the Country_Code enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be included in the Credit enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be included in the Credit enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be included in the Country_Code enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be in valid Internet email format.
Same as CALL, with no prefix or suffix.
Must be included in the Qsl_Rcvd enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be included in the Qsl_Sent enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must start with a digits only. Minus sign and decimal point are not allowed.
Must be digits only. Minus sign and decimal point are not allowed.
Must be within the limits of a band as defined in the Band enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be empty or a valid grid square.
Same as CALL, with no prefix or suffix.
Must be a value in the Qso_Upload_Status enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.

entry.para: Must be in format CC-XXX where:

listitem.para: CC is in the Continent enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml; and,

row.entry: Must be included in the Qsl_Rcvd enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be included in the Qsl_Sent enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be included in the Mode enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Same as CALL, with no prefix or suffix.
Same as CALL, with no prefix or suffix.

entry.para: Must be a valid prefix. To be valid, the prefix must be of the format:

listitem.para: One or two letters, followed by one or more digits
One digit followed by one letter, followed by zero or more digits.
One of the special prefixes defined in HamQSLer. At the moment, these special prefixes are defined in the program, but in future will be maintained in a data file.
For example: VP2V, R1MV

row.entry: Must be a value in the Propagation enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be a value in the Qso_Upload_Status enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be included in the Qsl_Rcvd enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be included in the Qsl_Via enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be included in the Qsl_Sent enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
Must be included in the Qsl_Via enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.
No validation is performed on QSO import. If this field contains only a callsign with no prefix or suffix, it is used in HamQSLer as the contacted station's QSL manager.
Must be included in the Qso_Complete enumeration in AdifEnumerations.xml.

entry.para: .Must contain exactly two counties. Each county must contain:

listitem.para: Two letter US state. See STATE for validation;
A comma; and,
A series of letters and space characters for the county name. The first character cannot be a space.

row.entry: Must contain either two or four Maidenhead grid locators. Each grid must be valid. No validation is performed to ensure that the grid locators are adjacent to each other.

section.title: QSO Validation
section.para: After a QSO record is created from the validated QSO fields, the imported QSO is checked to ensure that it contains the following fields:

listitem.para: Call;
Mode;
Start date;
Start time; and,
Band or frequency.

section.para: If the QSO does not contain these fields, the QSO is not added to the list of QSOs imported by HamQSLer.

section.title: QSO Field and Multi-Field Validation and Modification
section.para: The following table describes the field and multi-field validation and modifications that HamQSLer performs after a QSO has been validated.

entry.para: If BAND does not exist, a BAND field is created with a value matching the band that the frequency is within.

If BAND does exist, the BAND field is checked to ensure that the frequency specified in the FREQ field is within this band. If the frequency is not within the specified band, then the value of the BAND field is changed to correspond to the frequency.
If BAND_RX does not exist, a BAND_RX field is created with a value matching the band that the frequency is within.

If BAND_RX does exist, the BAND_RX field is checked to ensure that the frequency specified in the FREQ_RX field is within this band. If the frequency is not within the specified band, then the value of the BAND_RX field is changed to correspond to the frequency.
